thread.title: Footy’s back! Complete guide to summer of NRL
thread.title_full: Footy’s back! Complete guide to summer of NRL

title: Footy’s back! Complete guide to summer of NRL

organizations.name: warriors at central energy trust arena

text:
Source: FOX SPORTS WELL that was scary. 
It’s been 56 days since the Four Nations final, when we last saw a Steeden kicked in anger and 120 kilos of Shannon Boyd cutting about in short shorts. 
But that all changes in a mere matter of weeks, because the footy is back, and back with a vengeance. 
The first sultry weekend of February gives us crowd favourite the Auckland Nines, and kicks off the longest rugby league season in memory — clocking in at over 300 days by the time the World Cup final rolls round in December. 
Be it Nines, All Stars, World Club Challenge or your team’s trials we’ve got you covered with everything you need to know in our 2017 Pre-season Ultimate Guide. 
AUCKLAND NINES Players turn out for the 2017 Auckland Nines launch. Picture: Brett Costello Source: News Corp Australia 
When: February 4-5 
Where: Eden Park 
Where to watch: Live and exclusive on Fox Sports 
We all know the drill now, nine players a side, nine minutes a half and anything can happen. 
JT, Hayne, Johnson and the whole NRL gang will descend on Auckland for an action packed weekend with $2.3 million of prize money on offer and 16 coaches praying their stars get through unscathed. 
The 2017 edition will also see the controversial zero-tackle rule on 20-metre taps scrapped for the tournament. 
POOLS 
Piha: Dragons, Eels, Sea Eagles, Warriors 
Hunua: Cowboys, Roosters, Raiders, Rabbitohs. 
Rangitoto: Knights, Wests Tigers, Broncos, Storm. 
Waiheke: Sharks, Titans, Panthers, Bulldogs. 
TEAM-BY-TEAM BREAKDOWN (all local times) Jarryd Hayne will be on board for his first Auckland Nines appearance in February. Pic Darren England. Source: News Corp Australia 
Broncos: (day 1) Storm 2:15pm, Knights 5.45pm, (day 2) Tigers 12.15pm 
Raiders: (day 1) Rabbitohs 3:05pm, Cowboys 6.35pm, (day 2) Roosters 1:30pm 
Bulldogs: (day 1) Panthers 12:25pm, Titans 4.20pm, (day 2) Sharks 10:35am 
Sharks: (day 1) Titans 12pm, Panthers 3.55pm, (day 2) Bulldogs 10:35am 
Titans: (day 1) Sharks 12pm, Bulldogs 4.20pm, (day 2) Panthers 11am 
S ea Eagles: (day 1) Warriors 1:15pm, Eels 5:10pm, (day 2) Dragons 11:50am 
Storm: (day 1) Broncos 2:15pm, Tigers 6:10pm, (day 2) Knights 12:40pm 
Knights: (day 1) Tigers 1:50pm, Storm 6:10pm, (day 2) Storm 12:40pm 
Cowboys: (day 1) Roosters 2:40pm, Rabbitohs 7pm, (day 2) Rabbitohs 1:05pm 
Eels: (day 1) Dragons 12:50pm, Warriors 5:10pm, (day 2) Sea Eagles 11:25am 
Panthers: (day 1) Bulldogs 12:25pm, Titans 4:20pm, (day 2) Titans 11am 
Rabbitohs: (day 1) Raiders 3:05pm, Roosters 7pm, (day 2) Cowboys 1:05pm 
Dragons: (day 1) Eels 12:50pm, Sea Eagles 4:45pm, (day 2) Warriors 11:50am 
Roosters: (day 1) Cowboys 2:40pm, Rabbitohs 7pm, (day 2) Raiders 1:30pm 
Warriors: (day 1) Sea Eagles 1:15pm, Eels 4:45pm, (day 2) Dragons 11:50pm 
Tigers: (day 1) Knights 1:50pm, Storm 6:10pm (day 2) Broncos 12:15pm 
ALL STARS The Goanna: Expect Greg Inglis to pull one of these out in Newcastle. pic Mark Evans Source: News Corp Australia 
When: Friday, February 12 
Where: Hunter Stadium, Newcastle 
Anyone who questions this fixture’s place on the NRL calendar need only look to the good it does across the wider league community and sit back down. 
This year’s clash travels down the highway with Newcastle hosting this celebration of Indigenous footy and the game itself for the first time. 
The biggest and best are all on board as usual, with Kangaroos coach Mal Meninga steering the All Stars for the first time against his old Origin counterpart Laurie Daley 
The Women’s All Stars clash will act as the curtain raiser as the Indigenous girls look to avenge a 24-4 loss to the All Stars last year. 
World All Stars: Jarryd Hayne, David Mead, Joey Leilua, Konrad Hurrell, Nene Macdonald, Mitch Moses, Adam Reynolds, Nate Myles, Jake Friend, Jordan McLean, Gavin Cooper, Bryce Cartwright, Jake Trbojevic Interchange: Reagan Campbell-Gillard, Sosaia Feki, Sione Mata’utia, Sa, Lisone, Moses Mbye, Tepai Moeroa, Jordan Turner 
Indigenous All Stars: Jack Wighton, Blake Ferguson, Greg Inglis, Will Chambers, Dane Gagai, Johnathan Thurston, Ash Taylor, Ryan James, Nathan Peats, Andrew Fifita, Joel Thompson, Wade Graham, Sam Thaiday Interchange: Tyrone Peachey, Jack Bird, Leilani Latu, Latrell Mitchell, Aidan Sezer, Kyle Turner, Adam Elliott 
WORLD CLUB SERIES Cronulla take on Wigan for the title of best club in the world in February. Source: AAP 
When: February 18-19 
Where: UK 
The format has been scaled back given a bumper 2017 season is on the horizon, but this year’s clashes offer quality over quantity. 
NRL heavyweights Brisbane are on board again and will take on Super League grand finalist Warrington on the Saturday. 
Then Cronulla - fresh finally switching off the porch light left on for Harold Holt - face English powerhouse Wigan for the title of best club on the planet. 
February 18: v Warrington at Halliwell Jones Stadium, Warrington, UK, 8pm. 
February 19: v Warriors at Central Energy Trust Arena, Palmerston North, NZ, 2pm. 
TRIAL GAMES (all local times) Souths recruit Robbie Farah is pushing for a Charity Shield debut for his new club. Source: News Corp Australia

February 17: v Cowboys, Campbelltown Sports Stadium, 7:00pm.
